summary:
Ph.D. student at Rijksuniversiteit Groningen, working as an early stage researcher in the PerICo project under the Marie Skłodowska-Curie Innovative Training Network. My primary objective in this project is to identify novel peroxisomal membrane transport proteins using proteomics, high throughput screening of yeast libraries, and fluorescent microscopy with genetics tags for intracellular localization. 

I did my MSc. in Biology-Biotechnology at the University of Copenhagen and specializes in molecular biology, protein biochemistry and functional bioinformatics for nucleotide and peptide analysis.

Orcid ID: 0000-0002-7924-5814

projects:
[{'title': 'Energetic tapping points in photosynthetic systems - The possibility to redirect energy into enzymatic processes', 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}}, 'description': 'Most biological production organisms are expensive and requires substrates that can be used otherwise. Thus, the need for a more sustainable production system is wanted. By applying genetically modified photosynthetic organisms instead, the cost could be lowered, since their carbon source are the CO2 in the atmosphere.
However, what is the most efficient way to use such organisms and how can one obtain a high product yield. Due to evolutionary reasons, photosynthetic organisms absorb more energy than needed to shade for their competitors. Therefore, a lot of excess energy is found herein and enabling a recover of this energy thus seem reasonable via energetic tapping points.
By comparing previous work of others, to alike mechanisms in the photosynthetic systems involving energy tapping it should be possible to deduce potential tapping points.
This project presents a series of such theoretical energetic tapping points based on this knowledge.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Marc', 'last_name': 'Pilegaard Pedersen', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Ph.D. student hos Rijksuniversiteit Groningen'}, {'type': 'nonStandardizedContributor', 'first_name': None, 'last_name': None, 'name': 'Professor Poul Erik Jensen', 'headline': None}]}, {'title': 'Thesis project - Energy partitioning in the photosynthetic systems of light driven organisms via protein fusions', 'date': {'start': {'month': 11, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': 11, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}}, 'description': 'This project addresses the aspect of redirecting electrons from the photosynthetic machinery by bioengineering a fusion protein capable of such actions. Based on already existing knowledge, a fusion protein was designed as a modular fusion construct containing the P450 monooxygenase CYP79A1 from Sorghum bicolor, ferredoxin2 from Arabidopsis thaliana and a synthetic linker region spanning between these. The fusion was designed to directly uptake electrons from photosystem 1 via ferredoxin2 and transfer the electrons to CYP79A1 for synthesis of the molecule p-hydroxyphenylacetaldoxime from tyrosine. Five fusion constructs was designed only varying in the linker length from 7-27 amino acids with 5 increments, to test how variable linkers can affect the product formation based on the electron uptake from photosystem 1. The CYP79A1 was chosen as the catalyzing enzyme since it is the first enzymatic step in the already well-established biosynthetic pathway of dhurrin.
The fusions proteins were transiently expressed in tobacco (Nicotiana benthamiana), then translocated to the chloroplast and integrated into thylakoid membrane, which was proven by immunoblotting. Via light driven assays, the product synthesis were shown to be both light –and linker length dependent and product formation were observed for all fusion proteins.
The results showed that the fusion protein with shortest linker of 7 amino acids were able to support the highest relative level of p-hydroxyphenylacetaldoxime formed. However interestingly the 27 amino acid linker support the second highest product formation. By adding FNR and NADP+ to the light driven assays product formation were strongly decreased.
By increasing the ionic strength of the light driven assay it was possible to optimize the product formation and to a level higher than all native ionic strength assays.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Marc', 'last_name': 'Pilegaard Pedersen', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Ph.D. student hos Rijksuniversiteit Groningen'}, {'type': 'nonStandardizedContributor', 'first_name': None, 'last_name': None, 'name': 'Professor Poul Erik Jensen', 'headline': None}]}, {'title': 'Advanced Biotechnology and Intellectual Property Rights', 'date': {'start': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}}, 'description': 'Student project in collaboration with Chr. Hansen Holding A/S in optimizing biosynthetic pathways for heterologous expression and product synthesis in regard of pateting.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Marc', 'last_name': 'Pilegaard Pedersen', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Ph.D. student hos Rijksuniversiteit Groningen'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Annemette', 'last_name': 'Lyhne-Kjærbye', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Mikrobiolog hos Fødevarestyrelsen'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Jonas', 'last_name': 'Gensby', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Cand.scient'}]}, {'title': 'Comparison of receptors from Quorum sensing', 'date': {'start': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2013}, 'end': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2013}}, 'description': 'Comparison of receptors from Quorum sensing - The possibility for conserved segments.
This optional 7,5 ECTS point assignment is based on the knowledge about the inter bacterial communication system otherwise known as Quorum sensing. Further, with focus on the receptors which are able to perceive the autoinducers which is synthesized in a broad variety of bacteria, both in gram positive and gram negative bacteria.
Via multiple alignment of the amino acid sequence from different receptors which only can perceive the same autoinducer I have found different preserved sequence among these receptors.
Also, via the already determined tertiary structure of some receptors via X-ray crystallography or NMR I have found alike structural motifs and segments although the sequence identity only is around 15 %.
Finally, results of this kind can hopefully become useful in a near future where we can chemically design drugs which fit almost perfect to a receptors active site/binding pocket. For example when trying to antagonize substrates like autoinducers, with the purpose of designing a competitive inhibitor for a blockade of the signal cascade which is created when an autoinducers bind to its receptor.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Marc', 'last_name': 'Pilegaard Pedersen', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Ph.D. student hos Rijksuniversiteit Groningen'}, {'type': 'nonStandardizedContributor', 'first_name': None, 'last_name': None, 'name': 'Professor Hanne Ingmer', 'headline': None}]}, {'title': 'Inter prokaryotic interactions directed via Quorum sensing', 'date': {'start': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2013}, 'end': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2013}}, 'description': 'Bachelorproject; 
Many decades of research in the area of bacterial interaction has proved the existence of a delicate bacterial communication system now known as Quorum sensing. This system is based on the production of small chemical compounds that are exported out into the extracellular milieu, where they are perceived to measure the population density.
Thus, when prokaryotes live in a multispecies habitat this signal can either be exploited by some bacteria or used as a line of defence against other bacteria.
The prokaryote P. aeruginosa is the most extensively researched bacteria in the matter of Quorum sensing. From the current knowledge about Quorum sensing mediated inter bacterial interactions from P. aeruginosa I have created an interaction map with other prokaryotes. This map is based on the synthesized and hereafter exported autoinducers from P. aeruginosa.
Also, in this report I have pointed out some purely theoretical interactions among different prokaryotes. These interactions seem plausible and are based on their ability to synthesize autoinducers, perceive these and their ecological features. From this the hypothetical interactions could prove possible. Further, all of these interactions should collectively arise even more questions about the workings of Quorum sensing and what there can be done in the near future to understand these.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Marc', 'last_name': 'Pilegaard Pedersen', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Ph.D. student hos Rijksuniversiteit Groningen'}, {'type': 'nonStandardizedContributor', 'first_name': None, 'last_name': None, 'name': 'Professor Hanne Ingmer', 'headline': None}]}, {'title': 'Homogalacturonan biosynthesis in the Golgi', 'date': {'start': {'month': 11, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}, 'end': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2013}}, 'description': 'Recent research has provided that proteins involved in pectin synthesis might form protein complexes, located in the Golgi apparatus. The main group of these proteins is known as galacturonosyltransferases, GAUTs. It is hypothesized that at least 67 enzymatic reactions are involved in this synthetizing pathway. This leads to the assumption that a lot of other proteins and maybe bigger protein complexes participate in production of pectin polymers. Based on this knowledge about possible protein-protein interactions (PPIs) including GAUTs and other potential candidates we wanted to identify interactions between GAUT1 and GAUT6 and a selection of co-expressed genes chosen via bioinformatic approaches. This was done by performing a split-luciferase complementation assay (SLCA). Furthermore we wanted to explore interactions occurring between the different GAUT proteins we were interested in. For this purpose we performed a split-ubiquitin assay with a subsequent droptest including X-Gal overlay. In addition to this, and with the aim to identify other interaction partners of GAUT1, we screened a cDNA library, produced by us during the experiments. Results gained from the split-ubiquitin system confirmed some GAUT-GAUT interactions already known and new ones. On top of that a possible interaction between GAUT6 and XXT2, a xyloglucantransferase, was detected, which gives interesting opportunities for future perspectives. The data obtained by the SLCA showed promising results too, even though the PPIs among the GAUTs from the droptest could not be confirmed. 107 colonies, containing potential GAUT1 interactions, were acquired and need to be examined to identify the protein associations. Even though our results do not provide any definitive conclusions, they give rise to some new hypothesis about GAUTs and proteins involved in pectin biosynthesis, which needs further investigations.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Marc', 'last_name': 'Pilegaard Pedersen', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Ph.D. student hos Rijksuniversiteit Groningen'}, {'type': 'nonStandardizedContributor', 'first_name': None, 'last_name': None, 'name': 'Jonas Gensby', 'headline': None}, {'type': 'nonStandardizedContributor', 'first_name': None, 'last_name': None, 'name': 'Max Woweries', 'headline': None}, {'type': 'nonStandardizedContributor', 'first_name': None, 'last_name': None, 'name': 'Simon Erstad', 'headline': None}, {'type': 'nonStandardizedContributor', 'first_name': None, 'last_name': None, 'name': 'Annemette Lyhne-Kjærby,', 'headline': None}]}]

position_groups:
[{'company': {'id': 165742, 'name': 'Rijksuniversiteit Groningen', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C560BAQHjFD1KsBlUnQ/company-logo_400_400/0/1519868080428?e=1700092800&v=beta&t=zwHZthqGYeY_GDI5v0n8SgPTwr4MXQrF9poTgHWrNXU', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/school/rijksuniversiteit-groningen/', 'employees': {'start': 5001, 'end': 10000}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 3, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Faculty of Science and Engineering, Zernike Campus', 'date': {'start': {'month': 3, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'company': 'University of Groningen', 'description': "Early Stage Researcher in the Peroxisome Interactions and Communication (PerICo) Project as part of the Marie Skłodowska-Curie Innovative Training Network (ITN) mobility programme, funded by the European Union’s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under the Marie Sklodowska Curie grant agreement No. 812968, coordinated by Prof. Dr. Ida van der Klei (University of Groningen).

PerICo aims to uncover how peroxisomes, important cellular organelles, participate in the intricate cellular interaction and signaling network. In light of the current understanding of the central role of peroxisomes in a variety of metabolic diseases, cancer, and aging – this timely research programme will benefit society.

I'm currently working with yeast metabolic engineering ( S. Cerevisiae and H. Polymorpha), intra-cellular dual localization using multiple fluorescent probes (both stable genomic fusion integration e.g. GFP, DsRed, mKate2, and fluorescent molecules, Mitotracker + using endogenous promoters og overexpression promoters). I daily use Zeiss microscopes. Beside of this I design high-throughput screens for S. Cerevisiae with our partner collaborator at the Weizmann Institute of Science using Tecan robotics and spinning disk microscopes. Specifically we use the S. Cerevisiae overexpression, deletion, -and fluorescent tagged libraries. These libraries are mostly used for localization -and auxotrophy studies based on lack of specific metabolites and specific protein-protein interactions (PPI). Furthermore, I'm currently working with Applikon bioreactor system for specialized fermentor systems (chemostat) for cultivation of yeast for isolation of cellular micro-bodies used for proteomic analysis for protein discovery.", 'title': 'Ph.D. student, Marie Skłodowska Curie fellow', 'employment_type': 'Full-time'}]}, {'company': {'id': 9346863, 'name': 'Institut for Plante- og Miljøvidenskab, Københavns Universitet', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C4D0BAQHM-m6oFP1ZmA/company-logo_400_400/0/1579605555174?e=1700092800&v=beta&t=QcyNbG-g433c74ncEKn7L9VH9WePliuUjZTeeyJDu6U', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/company/department-of-plant-and-environmental-sciences-university-of-copenhagen/', 'employees': {'start': 501, 'end': 1000}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2017}, 'end': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Faculty of Science, Frederiksberg Campus', 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2017}, 'end': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}}, 'company': 'Department of Plant and Environmental Sciences, University of Copenhagen', 'description': 'Department of Plant and Environmental Sciences
Reseach assistant in the Section for Plant Glycobiology and work on the ASSEMBLY project.
The ASSEMBLY project aims to reconstruct the plant cell wall to produce bio-composite materials.

In this 1-year research position as a RA my tasks included;
 - Full process characterization 
 - Bioinformatic analysis (genomic promoter -and exome gene identification, isochizomere identification and removal, pointmutations, peptide translation, peptide folding, PyMol superimpositions, toxic gene analysis)
 - Molecular biology and cloning (vector backbone construction and interchangeable elements, restriction site cloning)
 - Heterologous protein expression and protein purification (E. coli, GE Life Science IMAC)
 - High throughput screening for cell wall carbohydrate binding interactions
 - Enzymatic bioassaying for cell wall carbohydrate activities', 'title': 'Research assistant', 'employment_type': 'Contract'}]}, {'company': {'id': 9346863, 'name': 'Institut for Plante- og Miljøvidenskab, Københavns Universitet', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C4D0BAQHM-m6oFP1ZmA/company-logo_400_400/0/1579605555174?e=1700092800&v=beta&t=QcyNbG-g433c74ncEKn7L9VH9WePliuUjZTeeyJDu6U', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/company/department-of-plant-and-environmental-sciences-university-of-copenhagen/', 'employees': {'start': 501, 'end': 1000}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 10, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': 10, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Faculty of Science, Frederiksberg Campus', 'date': {'start': {'month': 10, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': 10, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}}, 'company': 'Department of Plant and Environmental Sciences, University of Copenhagen', 'description': 'Department of Plant and Environmental Sciences
